Description:
From the mid-15th century until 1882, spring carnival in Rome closed with a horse race. Fifteen to 20 riderless horses, originally imported from the Barbary Coast of North Africa, ran the length of the Via del Corso, a long, straight city street, in about 2½ minutes.

Throughout his career, Géricault lovingly depicted the horse as a metaphor for unfettered emotion and power. The artist initially planned to paint a canvas of this subject more than 30 feet in width; he completed 20 small oil studies before abandoning the project. In other variations on this theme, Géricault set the race in ancient, rather than contemporary, Rome.

Exhibitions.Textblock: Millet and Barbizon Art. Matsumoto City Museum, Matsumoto City; Tokuyama City Museum of Art and History, Tokuyama; Kasama Nichido Museum, Kasama City; Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art, Kanazawa. 1996.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Triumph of French Painting: Masterpieces from Ingres to Matisse
Exhibitions.Textblock: Triumph of French Painting: Masterpieces from Ingres to Matisse. Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore; Philbrook Museum of Art, Tulsa; Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach; Dayton Art Institute, Dayton; Royal Academy of Arts, London; Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo. 2000-2002.
Reciprocal loan to Musee Calvet. Musee Calvet, Avignon. 2001.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Taste of Maryland: Art Collecting in Maryland 1800-1934
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Taste of Maryland: Art Collecting in Maryland 1800-1934. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1984.
Highlights from the Collection. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1998-2001.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Vive la France! French Treasures from the Middle Ages to Monet
Exhibitions.Textblock: Vive la France! French Treasures from the Middle Ages to Monet. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1999-2000.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: From Ingres to Gauguin: French Nineteenth Century Paintings Owned in Maryland
Exhibitions.Textblock: From Ingres to Gauguin: French Nineteenth Century Paintings Owned in Maryland. Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore. 1951.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Inaugural Exhibition at the Fort Worth Art Center
Exhibitions.Textblock: Inaugural Exhibition at the Fort Worth Art Center. Fort Worth Art Center, Fort Worth. 1954.

Medium: oil on paper, mounted on canvas
Provenance: Géricault Estate Sale, Paris, November 2-3, 1824, no. 81; Sale, A. M. Couvreur, Paris; Sale, E. Secrétan, Paris, July 1, 1889, no. 35; H. O. Havemeyer, 1889 [mode of acquisition unknown]; H. S. Henry, New York, 1899, by purchase [Durand- Ruel, as agent]; H. S. Henry Sale, New York, January 25, 1907, no. 21; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1907, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Riderless Racers at Rome
